bboxes.raw_text:
James A. Rork, administrator
director of the Arizona State
Employment Service. advises
1864 high school graduates to
consider their job future care
fully. He stated that in this JET
propelled automated age Of Elec-
tro-mechanical Innovations the
high school diplomas is not al
ways a passport into the better
jobs in a highly competitive labor
market without further training
or preparation.


Mr.. Rork invited those seeking
summer employment to make
early contact with the nearest
office Of the Arizona State EN-
ployment Service.


This past summer, according
to Mr.. Rork. the State Employ
ment Service found jobs for over
1900 high school graduates and
college students.

When the talented King Curtis
makes his cross-country tours
around the nation 8 leading night
clubs he will be following the
elegant tradition Of travelling in
a private railroad car.


The entertainer became a
member Of this select group Of
private railroad car owners late
last summer when he purchased
the famed Cannonball Adderley
Car which had been in storage
on the Long Island City tracks
Of the Pennsylvania Railroad.


Curtis also has his eyes on
the economic significance Of his
new travelling facility. He says
1t will be less expensive since
air travel and hotel bills would
mount to tremendous figures over
the long haul.


One portion of the car Is re-
served for members of his band,
says King. while the other halfis
his personal living quarters with
bedroom. two baths, living room,
sitting room and dining area
with a small kitchen attached.


The railroad car Is air con-
diuoned. with a deep burgundy
upholstery with walnut paneling.
There are also quarters for a
cook and two roomettes for staff.

DANBURY, Conn. Members
of the local branch of the Ma
tional ASS ociation for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People last
week, paraded in the rain for
nearly three hours outside a
downtown restaurant in protest
against the "lily-white" Ex-
change Club of Danbury, which
was having a meeting inside.


The NAACP group. a total of
so. was protesting the business
and professional mems club re-
striction of membership to
whites only" The national body,
headquartered in Toledo, Ohio,
dropped the Objectionable clause
from its constitution in 1861.
The local Exchange Club did not.


DR.. Frederick Adams, Danbury
NAACP president. said the DEM
onstration climaxed seven weeks
of fruitless negotiations with the
club. Club officials first agreed
to change the constitution, but
later to picket the Exchange Club
meetings until the bias clause Is
removed, DR.. Adams added.

WASHlNCTON-T The Defense De-
partment has ordered the end of
training of military personnel at
schools practicing discrimination.


Asst. Secretary of Defense Nor
man S. Paul ordered the halt in
90 days.


An estimated 100000 service

pers onnel are involved in various
educational programs.


Paul said each top official must
be sure that all facilities used in
the programs under his supervi-
sion do not discriminate because
of race or color in the admis-
sion or treatment of students.

Defense Dept. Moves
To End School Bias

HAS TRAIN CAR
